objectives: Search for signs of ancient microbial life and biosignatures
Collect and cache rock and soil samples for future return to Earth
Test oxygen production from the Martian atmosphere (ISRU demonstration)
Characterize Mars' geology and climate to prepare for human exploration
Demonstrate technology for future robotic and human exploration
Study the history and formation of Jezero Crater
funFacts: Perseverance carried the first helicopter to fly on another planet - Ingenuity, which has flown over 70 times, far exceeding its 5-flight mission
The rover is equipped with 23 cameras, more than any previous Mars mission, including 7 science cameras and 9 engineering cameras
It has a device called MOXIE (Mars Oxygen ISRU Experiment) that successfully produced oxygen from Mars' CO2 atmosphere multiple times, paving the way for future human missions
Perseverance is collecting samples in 43 titanium tubes that will be cached for a future Mars Sample Return mission planned for the 2030s
The rover landed on February 18, 2021, using a 'sky crane' maneuver with the help of a new terrain-relative navigation system
It carries a piece of Martian meteorite that fell to Earth as a calibration target for its SHERLOC instrument
Over 10.9 million names were etched onto three silicon microchips carried by Perseverance
The rover has a robotic arm that's 7 feet (2.1 meters) long and can drill into rocks to collect core samples
Perseverance recorded the first sounds ever captured on Mars using two microphones, including the sound of the Ingenuity helicopter flying
It landed in Jezero Crater, a 28-mile-wide ancient lake bed that existed 3.5 billion years ago and may preserve signs of ancient life
The rover can drive autonomously to avoid hazards using its advanced AutoNav AI system, covering up to 393 feet (120 meters) per day
Perseverance weighs 2,260 pounds (1,025 kg), slightly heavier than Curiosity
Its SuperCam instrument can analyze rocks and soil from up to 20 feet away using laser spectroscopy, camera imaging, and sound recording
The rover's wheels are slightly larger and more robust than Curiosity's, with thicker aluminum and new treads to prevent damage
Perseverance carries a radiation detector to help understand the radiation environment for future astronauts
The rover discovered organic molecules in multiple rock samples, though this doesn't confirm past life
It found rocks in Jezero Crater that have been altered by water multiple times, indicating a complex history
The mission cost approximately $2.7 billion, including development, launch, and operations
Perseverance's computers are RAD750 processors running at 200 MHz with 2 GB of flash memory and 256 MB of RAM
The rover can communicate with Earth at up to 2 Mbps during favorable orbital alignments via the Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter
